thread.title_full: How a hockey team led to the creation of Alabama's favorite signature beer

author: Carla Jean Whitley | cwhitley@al.com
title: How a hockey team led to the creation of Alabama's favorite signature beer
text:
Rocket Republic Mach 1 IPA isn't just Alabama's favorite signature beer. 
It's the beer that birthed the brewery. 
Eric Crigger and John Troy, who own the brewery along with their wives Tatum Crigger and Lynn Troy, were hockey buddies who enjoyed an occasional post-game beer. Home brewer Crigger often provided the sippable suds. One evening, he arrived with an India pale ale and pomegranate wheat beer in tow. 
"These are really, really delicious beers," Troy recalls saying. "You should make this." 
AL.com readers seem to agree; they voted for Rocket Republic Mach 1 IPA as Alabama's favorite signature beer. 
Within a month, the friends incorporated Rocket Republic. Within another month, they were brewing. 
The two beers that made such an impression on Troy remain on the brewery's menu as Mach 1 IPA and Pomegranate Planet. Rocket Republic's IPA embodies an East-Coast style, which is maltier than its West-Coast cousins. That's only one of the beer's distinguishing factors, they say. 
Mach 1 incorporates rye malt, which adds a spicy characteristic and smooths out the traditional IPA bitterness on first sip. But hop heads, don't assume this is a less-hoppy IPA. As it sits in the fermenter, Rocket Republic brewers add dry Centennial and Cascade hops in a process called late hopping or hop bursting. 
The result is a citrus-y flavor bomb that starts out easy and finishes with the pleasing bitterness for which IPAs are known. 
Crigger sometimes experiments with the IPA, adding 100-percent grapefruit juice, infusing it with tangerine slices or even Sumatran coffee beans. (If there's anything Crigger is as crazy about as beer, it's coffee, Troy says.) 
As Rocket Republic continues to grow, its owners are exploring canning and bottling options with the hope of distributing more beer outside of Madison County. They expect that distribution to begin next year. 
Crigger says, "Tap handles are finite. They rotate and they change at all times."
